body:
Druid purposefully tries to disconnect itself from any particular Hadoop version. With 0.x/1.x still in wide use, and 2.x very popular, and 3.x actively moving along, we need to do everything we can to make sure that the solution is easily used in whatever version the users decide to have on the backend.

As such, I think the `hadoop classpath` solution is preferred unless there is a particular reason that solution confounds other behaviors

To continue with my comments replied in line, druid users are really appreciating for the convenient extension loader mechanism in druid, but the bug just makes them confused.  I'm not sure but I think it may be caused by the customized class loader in Druid rather than about HDFS itself, because the `hadoop classpath` solution proves that it should be OK in traditional class path loader for `hadoop-hdfs` but how should it not work for Druid? Especially when druid's log prints:

```
INFO [main] io.druid.initialization.Initialization - Added URL[file:/home/druid/.m2/repository/org/apache/hadoop/hadoop-hdfs/2.3.0/hadoop-hdfs-2.3.0.jar]
```

Surely, I also agree with the opinion about disconnecting Druid with any particular Hadoop version. So i think we have two options here:
- **Option 1:** If druid is still willing to help users to load all jar dependencies like what `hdfs-storage-extension` does for us, it should fix the bug as in this PR. And in fact it has nothing to do hadoop version, because `hadoop-hdfs` basic API is very stable and mature, and they seems intended to let their users to handle about it.
- **Option 2:** If druid really prefers users to add hadoop related dependencies by hands, the POM scope of `hadoop-client`  dependency here [extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml#L58](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/extensions/hdfs-storage/pom.xml#L58) should be changed from `compile` to `provided`, right? And it should also make sure Druid module loader not to load additional dependent `hadoop-hdfs` jars into local MAVEN repository, otherwise the JVM will always load at least two different versions of `hadoop-hdfs` jars which may cause some other unknown and confused problems:
  
  ```
  $ lsof -p 17094 | grep hadoop-hdfs
  java    17094 druid  mem    REG              252,0  5783912   774885 /home/druid/.m2/repository/org/apache/hadoop/hadoop-hdfs/2.3.0/hadoop-hdfs-2.3.0.jar
  java    17094 druid  mem    REG              252,0  7822243   774161 /usr/hdp/2.2.0.0-2041/hadoop-hdfs/hadoop-hdfs-2.6.0.2.2.0.0-2041.jar
  java    17094 druid  229r   REG              252,0  7822243   774161 /usr/hdp/2.2.0.0-2041/hadoop-hdfs/hadoop-hdfs-2.6.0.2.2.0.0-2041.jar
  java    17094 druid  472r   REG              252,0  5783912   774885 /home/druid/.m2/repository/org/apache/hadoop/hadoop-hdfs/2.3.0/hadoop-hdfs-2.3.0.jar
  ```

Any plans for updating docs? From what I understand having shardSpecs defined is a must for multiple realtime nodes ingesting same datasource and Druid is for large data streams (probably always running with multiple realtime nodes). I think it should be documented as soon as possible.

In fact only the requirement @swistakm mentions is documented (http://druid.io/docs/latest/Realtime-ingestion.html) but not any of the types and when you'd use which. I am working on adding some docs around this.

CI failed only on java 8 on

```
Failed tests:   testQueryCancellation(io.druid.query.ChainedExecutionQueryRunnerTest)
```
Unit tests for this class of problem are extremely difficult to write.

Difference to 0.6.x:

In 0.6.x the events were placed based on `key` into `facts` rather than on a separate `aggList`. 

Note that in 0.7.x, the facts table is to assist in finding the offset into the on/off heap data store which houses the actual data. This is different than 0.6.x where it stored the data itself.
Travis CI failed java8 only
We also need to add conversion for cache settings

``` properties
druid.announcer.type=batch
druid.curator.compress=true
```

settings can be removed if set to those specific values, since they are now the defaults.

``` properties
druid.db.connector.useValidationQuery
```

should be removed, since it does not exist anymore and is always true
@drcrallen @nishantmonu51 I added test case and did some code clean up. And sorry for taking so long.

Thanks @flowbehappy  few more comments:

If a dimension is called "id" I would expect it to be a high cardinality dimension rather than just "`default`". Is "id" supposed to be relatively high cardinality in this case?

@fjy @cheddar @xvrl (and @gianm for fyi): I find the cases in the unit test kind of odd. identical rows when added cause the aggregates to fire multiple times. Specifically, having 4 threads adding the exact same rows yields 4x the (longSum/doubleSum) aggregates of 1 thread adding the rows. Is this the behavior that is desired?

My initial inclination is that posting identical rows to the incremental index would be idempotent. which it currently is not.

If adding the same number of rows using 1 or 4 threads yields different results, that would be a major bug. I wonder if it has to do anything with the switch to using a ThreadLocal inputRow for aggregation in 0.7.

@xvrl It's adding the identical rows in 1 vs 4 threads.

For example, if your pool of rows is (row1, row2, row3) then adding that _set_ of rows in 1 thread, or adding in _each_ of 4 concurrent threads yields different results. I haven't attempted to add the set _among_ 4 threads.
in "each" I mean Thread1{(row1,row2,row3)}  Thread2{(row1,row2,row3)}    Thread3{(row1,row2,row3)}  for "among" was meaning Thread1{(row1)}  Thread2{(row2)}    Thread3{(row3)}
I'm thinking the onheap might work well as an on heap bytearray backed buffer of some kind, then both on and off can share a lot more logic.
CI failed on java8 again...
Again, TravisCI failed on Java8 (fine on java7)
@drcrallen Totally agree.  I will generate another more real test data.
closing in favour of another one having write access..
Fixes #1032
Victim of #1032
Victim of #1032
Victim of #1032
Thanks for the catch and contrib!
@andresgomez92 did you get a chance to look at my comment?
This is failing travis-ci
Was just curious in how this differs in the problems it solves to the Docker druid deployment?
There's a pr for a sharding section for 0.6.x. One for 0.7.x coming up shortly to close this issue.
This PR also ensures that any schemas used in 0.6.x will work in 0.7.x
Submitting this on behalf of @textractor
Going forward, we require all pull requests to have a meaningful title and description about the pull request. Please fix.
I am closing this. There are no changes whatsoever.
I had a set of comments for these docs already.
Duplicated by #1040
What's the status on this?  Would be helpful.
travis CI failed due to #1032, passing with Java7
Fixed by #1042
@metacret I believe this is the issue you are encountering with approximate histograms. The work-around is to give the post-aggregator a different name than the aggregator.
Thanks  a lot. I will ask internal users to change post-aggregator name.
@metacret You are welcome. I believe this bug is not new, and has been around for a very long time.
Sorry, I haven't had much free time. I'll try to end it at end of the week.
Hi @luxuec : can you please provide more information on this, like an example use case?
Is this a duplicate of #1053 ?

Not much. This is partly to give people an easy option to run a druid cluster and partly to show ways to launch druid components programatically. Since it's all self-contained in an extension it could easily be its own repository and not part of the mainline druid branch.

I would prefer to leave async logging disabled by default as it currently is and just give an example of how to configure it in the config file? By default I believe it is more important to have full logs in case of a crash rather than having good performance with debug logs enabled.
@xvrl : Reverted default to prior behavior and added documentation on how to modify behavior if desired.
doesn't look like this has gotten much love lately, closing unless someone wants to pick it up again.
Keeping this one open as it has more info and closing #1052
Duplicated by #1053
I did move some comments from INFO --> DEBUG in some of the chatty classes, @xvrl : would you rather have them back to INFO?

your observation is correct, IngestSegmentFirehose works by iterating over all the available segments and emmitting the events for each segment or partition one by one, It should be fine to emit the events out of order of timestamps as IndexTask does not place any such restriction on the order of events on the firehose. 

can you explain more on what is the issue that you are facing ?

Can we please require rebasing pull-requests going forward to avoid needless cluttering of the commit history? Merge commits are especially annoying because they make it hard to understand the changes made.
Hello @nicktate . Thanks for the PR!  Can you please explain a little more on the issue you were encountering?

@drcrallen The new ingestion schema moves the parser underneath `ioConfig`. The S3 firehose expected the parser to be defined inside it (per the old schema), but the new schema follows more of a true "factory" pattern. The parser should no longer be tightly coupled to the firehose, but it had left a null precondition check that caused the index task to fail if you didn't leave the parser inside the firehose definition. I left the parser property for backwards compatibility in-case people were still using the 0.6.x ingestion schema.
fixed by #1029
fixed by #1026
fixed by #1017
fixed by #891
seems to be a duplicate of #55
fixed by #876
Druid is now case-sensitive starting with 0.7.x
@nicktate we are removing support for the old ingestion schema in 0.7, so we can probably remove the field entirely. @fjy can you confirm?

We looked at skipping v8 columns and creating v9 columns directly for Druid 0.7.0. It turns out that creating v8 followed by conversion to v9 is still faster than creating v9 columns directly in the current incarnation of the code, due to the fact that v8 serialization walks the rows once to create all the columns vs. v9 code still requires walking the rows multiple times.
@xvrl yes, we can remove the field directly. It was left there for backwards compatibility and should be removed.
@andresgomez92 did you guys sign a CLA? I don't recall
closing since this needs to be revisited in terms of behavior changes.
This has been fixed in 0.7.0
can you try somewhere without a firewall and see if you still have the same problem?
@fjy Yeah, my guys signed a CLA.

@haoch : Just FYI, there is [a discussion](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/druid-development/charles/druid-development/LtDiYzph7II/Ky93xVivCGwJ) about how how to handle dependencies going forward, which is part of why this PR isn't getting traction yet.
This isn't done yet, it needs to get reworked a bit so we will do that and resubmit at some point.
Closing as not really necessary

Adding more information:

for my use case, when running index task on a data source that has 36 partitions (partition number 2~37),  
IngestSegmentFirehoseFactory.java throws NPE in places getChunk(0). 
IndexerDBCoordinator.java throws NPE in places getChunk(0).
Right now the incremental index row adding is very single-threaded. Do you have any sort of profile to show the bottleneck is completely in the firehose rather than in the incrementalIndex?

What I am seeing is the generateSegment() is one of the places that can speed up. Based on my use cases, I execute index task 3 times faster by running generateSegment() in 8 threads(8 shard partitions). Also IncrementalIndex.add() is called in generateSegment(), if I understand correctly.
Hi luxuec, can you share the logs with complete stack trace for more detials ?

I think the title of the issue is a bit misleading, generateSegment() is part of indexTask not the firehose, 
will it be better framed as - "Optimize IndexTask to generate multiple partitions concurrently" ?

If my search is correct, this would make only the Kafka firehose factories and IngestSegment use the dimension exclusions. If this PR is really to fix dimension exclusions, then please take a look at the other firehose factories that come stock with druid (or stock extensions) and add their handling as needed.
can we get a sense how much this improves overall ingestion performance?

@xvrl : the performance bottlenecks are not often in this particular code branch. I originally set out to fix `OffheapIncrementalIndex` and ended up doing the removing of locks as a bit of a side effect.
I'm trying to run more tests on groupBy to see if there are notable performance differences though.

Also of note: the on heap and off heap are now comparable in their performance when used in groupBy queries. They are close enough to where I don't trust simple benchmarks on my laptop to say which clearly wins out.
can we add tests, I remember we had similar problems with excluding timestamp / metrics columns in the regular indexing spec that haunted us for some time. See `DataSchemaTest`
@xvrl : I fixed it so async writes work.
Can we please add a unit test? Also, I think protobuf parser probably doesn't use dimension exclusions either and probably should at some point
+1 I believe this is merge-able
Before we merge can we add comments to indicate the purpose of the second hash map. It wouldn't be obvious out of context.
Make sense. Changed the title. thanks.

I am using 0.6.169.
@xvrl : comment added
I'm doing another pass on OffHeap's DimDim stuff to remove some of the loops
Ok, I think I removed all the loops.
